original_title: Sri Lanka to repeal controversial NMRA drug regulator law
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka plans to repeal the controversial National Medical Regulatory Authority (NMRA) law Health Minister Keheliya Rambukwelle has said in a twitter.com message.
“Had productive meeting [with President Ranil Wickremesinghe] on a few issues,” he wrote.
“[First and most] important, NMRA & SLMC acts are to be completely repealed to allow a more open & fair market.”

1/3Had a productive meet w/Pres @RW_UNP on a few issues. Reform is imperative given the free reign that chaos enjoys in the form of those who have ill political intentions.1st & most important, NMRA & SLMC acts are to be completely repealed to allow a more open & fair market.
The NMRA added additional regulatory burdens amid charges of corruption.
The agency also imposed price controls in crisis situations including on face masks triggering shortages in addition to controlling drug prices.
When the price control agency started, analysts warned that the best way to make sure that drugs were affordable was to bring laws to control the central bank.

The agency by then already started to print money to boost growth under flexible inflation targeting, with the International Monetary Fund giving it technical assistance to calculate a potential output.
An unrestrained central bank will make all goods expensive, not just drugs, analysts pointed out.

The Health Minister’s twitter message came after several patients died with apparently contaminated or sub-standard Indian drugs.
Sri Lanka will seek guidance from the World Health Organization to implement an accredited ‘Benchmark 4’ lab – the highest level of accreditation – for drugs testing in Sri Lanka.
Generic drugs come in a variety of qualities depending on the manufacturer. No clinical trials are performed to prove the efficacy of generics unlike the ‘original’ drug.
